Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Merger Analysis of Multisided Platforms: An Application to the Used Heavy Duty Truck Auction Market

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to test economic theories about the effects of market competition on firms providing multisided platforms. A multisided platform facilitates interactions between two or more groups of participants. For example, a firm that sells auction services is connecting sellers with buyers. This project will develop new economic theory and will test the theory using data from auction sales of used heavy-duty trucks in the United States. The data analysis will examine the effects of a specific previous merger in this industry to see if and how the merger reduced competition. The methods developed in this project can also be used to examine other markets with competition between between multisided platform firms. Policymakers in the US are asked to evaluate proposed mergers to determine whether the merger might reduce competition. This is a difficult task for these types of merger, since the evaluation has to take into account both how the platforms interact and how the merger might change interactions. This project will develop and demonstrate one way to evaluate these factors. Preserving and strengthening competition strengthens the U.S. economy as a whole.

The project will extend the existing theoretical models of multisided platforms by including both horizontal differentiation between platforms and vertical differentiation among goods. According to the model constructed in the project, the higher fees charged by the platforms along with the merger have a heterogeneous impact on sellers with goods at different quality levels. When there are different indirect network effects among the groups on these platforms, it can trigger a change of quality structure across platforms. This structural change is more significant if there is less horizontal differentiation between platforms, which can make the number of participants more elastic to the fees and the indirect network effect. These findings are consistent with transaction data collected from the U.S. used heavy-duty truck auction market. According to the data, the high-quality trucks sold on the offline platform are valued more than the ones sold on the online platform. After the merger of the leading offline and online auction platforms, the offline platform charges a higher fee and uses a cross-platform information policy to reduce the search friction across the two platforms. These policy changes affect the decisions of buyers and sellers, resulting in a quality structure change on these two platforms: low-quality trucks are more likely to be transacted on the online platform, and high-quality trucks tend to be transacted on the offline platform. The difference in transaction prices on these platforms becomes more significant than before. The project will focus on this possible market evolution caused by the merger. After performing a structural estimation based on the model, the project will investigate the welfare implication of the merger on different groups and show several ways to improve the platform's revenue or social welfare. The method and results used in this project are especially useful when the markets have vertically differentiated goods, such as the health insurance market and the peer-to-peer lending market. The project can help us to understand the potential heterogeneous impact of mergers on different groups in those markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project are to understand the effects of mergers between multisided platforms better and present meaningful policy implications regarding platform mergers. The questions the project tries to answer include but are not limited to (1) what things the merged platforms can do to make their customers better off; (2). how large the efficiency can be compared to market power; (3). how welfare is split among different groups; (4). what the merged platforms can do to improve their revenue and social welfare. 

To answer the questions raised in the project, the project analyzes a recent merger in the U.S. heavy equipment market. It develops and estimates a structural model applicable to this platform market using the data observed from this market. The following are the major activities have done so far: (1). collecting relevant data from this platform market; (2). building a new structural model that is suitable to this auction transaction platform; (3) estimating the structural model using the collected data; (4). performing several counterfactuals based on the estimates; (5). summarizing all the findings in a paper. 

The results show that, after the merger, when two platforms keep separately but facilitate buyers? search and multihoming, namely, to search on two platforms, it can increase the efficiency of matching between buyers and sellers and raise their welfare.

For the merger in the U.S. used heavy equipment auction platform market, the estimated lower search costs after the merger can increase the total welfare by more than 8% in the baseline model, in which 6% comes from better matches, and the rest comes from saving in search costs. Although the merged platforms charge a higher commission, the total surplus of buyers and sellers can increase by more than 7%. The efficiency gain found in this paper could also exist in other platform mergers and should be set against loss from higher market power in those cases. 

In addition to the main results, the project analyzes the additional welfare effect from a possible change on the supply side following the merger. The way to construct the possible change is motivated by the data: post-merger, high-quality goods are more likely to be listed offline, and low-quality goods are more likely to be listed online. The results show that separating goods into different platforms according to their quality can generate additional benefits: specifically, with the post-merger search costs, it can increase the total trading surplus by about 2%. This is because it can help buyers with different quality preferences to target the goods they prefer more easily.

Based on the paper generated in the project, the project mainly makes two contributions. The first contribution is providing the first evaluation of a change in platform design that is commonly associated with platform mergers in which both platforms exist post-merger. Most existing platform literature focuses on traditional media markets and the mechanisms used in one online platform. The trade-off between changes in search costs and other policy changes has not been clearly discussed while considering the competition and mergers between platforms. To the extent that it is not easy for firms to facilitate multihoming prior to mergers, in the language of the Horizontal Merger Guidelines, these benefits are cognizable efficiencies that could be set against market power created by a merger. The policy implications generated in this project could be considered by agencies when they conduct merger analysis of platforms.

The second contribution is to develop a new buyer search model that combines choices regarding whether to multi-home, how many truck auctions to search, and which auction to enter. This model, combining search with auction entry, can be applied to other transaction platforms, especially for the ones where products are differentiated and sold by auction. The project uses new data to estimate the model in an efficient way. 

The Co-PI Xinlu Yao, who is a graduate student, has been fully involved in all parts of the project (model development, data preparation, estimation, writing, and presentation), and the project has been valuable in developing her modeling, computational, and presentation skills. The paper was used as the main chapter of her doctoral dissertation.

The paper generated in this project is presented in the 19th Annual International Industrial Organization Conference, the 2021 China Meeting of the Econometric Society, the Young Economist Symposium 2020, seminar in the Economics Department of Maryland, seminar in the Marketing Department of Purdue, seminar in the Bank of Canada, and seminar in the Compass Lexecon. During the presentations of the paper generated in this project, it has got many good feedbacks from people in different fields, such as professors in economics and marketing, and experts in the Bank of Canada and Compass Lexecon. The paper helps people to understand the mergers of platforms better.
